p: Chlorophylls and their derivatives have been extensively studied with emphasis on their in vitro antimutagenic effects against numerous dietary and environmental mutagens [ 63] and were shown to possess anticancer properties and could play significant roles in cancer prevention [ 64, 65]. The concentrations of the contents of seaweed pigments (total carotenoids, chlorophylls a and b) in the present study clearly demonstrated that marine seaweed-derived pigments were important free radical scavengers able to diminish cancer development.
